STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 6, 2023
James Risinger
MONROE COUNTY YOUTH CENTER
3600 S CUSTER RD,
MONROE, MI, 48161-9058
Re: License #: CO580201307
Dear James Risinger:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing

4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
COF Rule 400.10113 Employee records
• (1) Employee records shall be maintained for
each employee and shallinclude all of the
following information: (d) Three references
which are obtained before employment from
persons unrelatedto the employee.
Two of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document three completed
employee references.

COF Rule 400.10113 Employee records
• (1) Employee records shall be maintained for
each employee and shall include all of the
following information: (b) Verification of
education where minimum education
requirements are specified by rule.
One of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document verification of
education as required by policy.
COF Rule 400.10113 Employee records
• (1) Employee records shall be maintained for
each employee and shallinclude all of the
following information: (f) A written evaluation of
the employee's performance within the first 6
months of each position designated by these
rules and annually thereafter.
One of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document the completion of
an annual evaluation.
COF Rule 400.10115 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers
• (1) A facility shall document that each employee
and each volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more
than 2 consecutive weeks is free from
communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from
communicabletuberculosis shall be verified
within the 3-year period before employment and
shall beverified every 3 years after the last
verification.
One of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document verification of TB
testing consistent with CDC guidelines.
COF Rule 400.10309 Dental care

• (1) A facility shall document the provision of a
dental examination and treatment for each
resident who is 3 years of age and older. A
dental examination within 12 months before
admission shall be documented or there shall be
an examination not later than 3 months after
admission. Reexamination shall be provided at
least annually.
Two of three open treatment case files failed to document completion of a
dental exam as required.
COF Rule 400.10317 Updated service plan
• (3) The updated service plan shall include all of
the following information: (c) A release plan. The
plan shall be developed and recorded in the
updated services plan before the release date
and shall include a projected release date,
projected next placement, and action steps
necessary to accomplish the plan.
Two of three treatment updated service plans failed to document a release
plan as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided to the agency surrounding the completion
of six-month and annual evaluations. Agency reminded that all evaluations
must be completed and signed by both employee and supervisor by the due
date.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• N/A - No consultation was provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency had one CAP that was approved and implemented at the conclusion of the
2022 interim review. The agency was found in non-compliance with licensing rule
R. 400.10139. The CAP was approved, and the agency has demonstrated and
documented compliance.
Financial Overview
A copy of the annual financial report was provided for review. There were no areas
of concern noted for the agency. There were found to be in good financial status.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
N/A
Staff and Youth Interviews
A total of three staff were interviewed during this evaluation. They included the
Chief Administrator, supervisor and front-line staff. All staff expressed positive
feedback about employment with the agency and the commitment to child safety.
Three youth were interviewed during the annual review. All three youth provided
positive feedback regarding the facility and interactions with staff. Specifically,
they all stated that staff are supportive and demonstrate respect. Two of the three
expressed a desire for staff to be more consistent with enforcement of rules or
guidelines.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency was completed and found to be well maintained. No
areas of concern were noted. Chief Administrator was excited to show consultant
an area where the agency hopes to incorporate a larger garden for youth to work
in and sleeping units that had been painted and upgraded to include strength-
based messages for youths.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
10/05/2023
_____________________________________________________________________
Cassandra Thomas Date
Licensing Consultant
